patterns.pattern: First-time contributor with focused, single-category scope and narrow component area has moderate merge likelihood, offset by lack of prior engagement history
Author with prior merge rate significantly above 24% baseline demonstrates predictive capability independent of PR scope; higher rates correlate with acceptance
Low merge authors (5+ prior PRs with <5% merge rate) are deterministic rejection signal even in high-priority categories
Multi-channel PRs from first-time contributors violate architectural constraints and carry high rejection risk
Explicit size labels (XS, S, M) provide independent quality signal; XS and S historically stronger merge rates than L/XL
Bug fixes and maintenance changes (targeted scope, clear intent, referenced issues) have higher acceptance than feature additions or refactors for equivalent author credentials
Documentation-only PRs from first-time contributors have lower baseline success (~20-30%) despite low code risk
Revert PRs require consensus and are contentious; first-time contributors lack social capital for reversals
Infrastructure/daemon-level changes from first-time contributors face higher scrutiny despite technical correctness; system-wide impact requires established trust
Experienced-contributor or trusted-contributor labels strongly predict merge when combined with author merge rate >24%
Missing LoC data combined with first-time author status and unknown size label increases uncertainty and lowers merge probability
Bot accounts with trivial scope changes (model list additions, generic maintenance) lack credibility signals and face dismissal
Extension-related work carries elevated risk per architectural guidelines; requires explicit maintainer approval or experienced contributor status
High-priority categories (agents, gateway, commands, cli) elevate merge likelihood for focused fixes; baseline uplift ~15-25% over docs/low-volume areas
Critical path changes (cron logic, race conditions, security hardening) require higher evidence threshold from new contributors; scope risk outweighs category strength
Author engagement history (2-10 prior PRs with 50%+ merge rate) indicates capability and offsets first-time author rejection bias for focused changes
Maintainer labels (has_maintainer_label, trusted_contributor) act as credibility amplifiers; presence strongly improves acceptance probability
